1. Configure a build task in tasks.json:
"group": {
        "kind": "build",
        "isDefault": true
},
2. Start that task by pressing Ctrl+Shift+B
3. "Fetching build tasks" appears on status bar. This stays there for a few seconds. This message didn't appear on the previous release and the start of the build task appeared to be faster.

data.title: Installation from source
data.body:
Hey there,
I took on the challenge to install vscode on void linux from source. The installation doesn't list all dependencies I needed. These were pkg-config, libXScrnSaver, gconfmm. Now its working, with the only exception being the integrated terminal. Would be neat if you could update the installation notes.

data.title: Write guide how to support language servers on multi folder workspaces.
Semantics of "Discard All Changes" in Source Control panel considered harmful
data.body:
I was curious what happened to the reporter of #32405 so I did some tests, and while he might have some self-inflicted problem being taken serious, I also think there's more to it.

This is vscode 1.14.2 on Linux x86_64.

Steps to Reproduce:

1.

    mkdir vs-code-vc-test
    cd vs-code-vc-test
    ls >test-1.txt
    ls >test-2.txt

2. In vscode: "File" -> "Open Folder" -> Open the directory just created

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/240625/29263990-91b97c5c-80db-11e7-9996-47b6c0ede5be.png)

3. On the "Source Control" Tab: Click "Initialize Repository" (but, see below)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/240625/29264076-ec012e6c-80db-11e7-8b4f-1974a6fab400.png)

This is displayed like this in vscode

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/240625/29264103-09e764fa-80dc-11e7-8b49-794db9df9ffd.png)

and the state of the repository is reported by `git status` like this, as expected

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/240625/29264209-674523bc-80dc-11e7-8cf9-9dbf5d9add80.png)

4. Stage file test-1.txt and commit it

5. Make some random change to the content of file test-1.txt

This is shown like this in vscode

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/240625/29265006-a061d336-80df-11e7-8814-62ec38123b19.png)

and reported like this by `git status`

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/240625/29265032-b9cd0426-80df-11e7-9a12-cdeb32286091.png)

6. Select "Discard All Changes" from the overflow menu (three dots in in the upper right corner) of the "Source Control" Tab and confirm the warning dialog that appears:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/240625/29264474-8558b476-80dd-11e7-9383-1f847027dddb.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/240625/29264526-c8a1b354-80dd-11e7-82d7-76e7b0066998.png)

7. Result: test-1.txt is reset to the version that was committed (as expected), and **test-2.txt is deleted although it was never added to git**!

There are multiple things that I consider problematic:

1. Given the two menu entries "Unstage all changes" and "Discard all changes" I would have expected "Unstage ..." to do the equivalent of `git reset --mixed` (what it seems to do) and "Discard ..." to just do the equivalent of `git reset --hard`, but the latter really also does a `git clean` which **removes all untracked files** from the working tree! That's such a dangerous command that I argue there shouldn't even be an UI entry for it. 
2. There doesn't seem to be a equivalent to just `git reset --hard` in the menu, which I would consider
(more) useful and might give a hint that "Discard changes" is really even more dangerous. The thing 
about the warning is: If I want to do a `git reset --hard` I **expect** a warning (and would therefore confirm it) because it **is** dangerous.
3. Even if that's really how "Discard changes" is supposed to work, then the warning should not just read 
"Are you sure you want to discard ALL changes?" (is an untracked file really a "change"?) but clearly state the fact that untracked files will be removed and maybe name (some of) them.
4. Minor nitpick: I think the safer option of the two ("Unstage...") should come first in the menu.

What **might** make things worse (and the scenario from #32405 more plausible) is that I **think** that during my tests vscode twice initialized a git repository in the current directory on its own, that is, without me clicking "Initialize Repository" or running "git init" on the command line. I haven't really been able to reproduce that, though, so it might be just me being confused. It just mention it in case someone also encountered that before or comes up with a scenario where this might happen.

- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:26:08.116Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.12.4-1-ARCH
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
python|don|0.7.0
json-tools|eri|1.0.2
Go|luk|0.6.63
cpptools|ms-|0.12.2
polymer-ide|pol|0.6.0

data.title: File fast find in file explorer
data.body:
It would be useful to have a fast find feature in the files explorer. For example node_modules can be a very long list of files to scroll through

The usual key sequence triggered search would be just fine. Eg as In windows explorer

data.title: "Go to definition" - Node.js - Not working with simple example
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:16:18.034Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
sublime-keybindings|ms-|2.9.1

My "project" has just 2 files: ``app.js`` and ``hey.js``. In the example below, VSCode isn't able to find the ``hello`` function in the other file.

![](https://i.imgur.com/IYAE8pp.png)

If I declare ``hello`` local by putting ``var`` before, then it works fine, but this is not what I want since I need to call the function from ``app.js``:

![](https://i.imgur.com/eVrPkBt.png)

This issue seems to happen with anything declared in the global scope, including variables.

Do I have to add something else in order to fix this? Am I missing some configuration step? Keep in mind that I'm not following any coding good practices here.

- VSCode "About" (tested with both Stable and Insider builds):
![](https://i.imgur.com/sW4ZzWv.png)
![](https://i.imgur.com/WRREXnz.png)

data.title: SourceControl shows 99+ Changes after git checkout master - git pull
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15 64x
- OS Version: win10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. what i did in git-bash on windows: 
git checkout master
git pull
2. it shows 99+ changes in git
i close and restart git and it shows no changes

Master branch was far behind so probably node_modules was not included before pull.

I think vs code switches to lightweight git mode when there are a lot of changes.
But then would it not update changes when i go to the source control tab?

I waited for a bit but it wouldn't go to zero, only after restart. (i restarted to check, so sorry i have no screenshot)

data.title: Long string in json gets truncated

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add a json with very long string in Chinese like:
`{
	"a": "本網站是由我們根據「現況」而提供的。我們不會對本網站的運作，或其內容的準確性，週全性或完整性，或所載的服務，作出任何明示或暗示的陳述或保證。在適用法律許可的最大限度內，我們不作任何明示或暗示的保證，包括（但不限於）對下列各項的任何陳述或保證：
- 本網站可供隨時使用，或不會受到干擾或全無錯誤，或故障的修正；
- 本網站所載任何內容的準確性、週全性或完整性；
- 本網站所載任何服務的可銷售性、品質標準或是否符合任何特定用途；

data.title: Emmet in preprocessors?
data.body: Hello! "Emmet 2.0" works correctly with preprocessors? Specifically interested in the stylus and jade. My abbreviation is not correctly unfolding, I have to choose from the proposed options arrow control. Is it a feature, or a bug? Sorry for my english =)

data.title: Emmet for recovery build 1.15
data.body: This PR consists cherry-picked commits from master branch to enable emmet expanding on tab

data.title: Support "loaded scripts" for chrome-debug
data.body:
- Part 1, hook it up to 'chrome'-type sessions. We can do this by 
  - Changing loadedScripts.ts to listen for new 'chrome' sessions - it might be weird that a built-in extension has this link to an optional extension, although it's a special case
  - Or moving that code to vscode-chrome-debug-core, where node-debug2 can configure it for 'node' and 'node2' sessions, and vscode-chrome-debug can configure its own copy for 'chrome' sessions.

- Part 2, improve it to display URLs correctly, by parsing the protocol/hostname if present and combining it into a single row
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/323878/29259121-c46a0246-8074-11e7-974e-7ad289508219.png)

data.title: Can't search root folder names in quickopen
data.body:
- Have a multiroot workspace with folders 'foo' and 'bar'
- Search 'foo' in quickopen
- No results
- Search 'f1' where 'f1/foo.txt' is some file in 'foo'
- It appears

data.title: Incorrect pop-up color picker position
data.body:
Problem:
- When you hover on rgb, hsl functions on the right side of code scope, then color picker pop-up appears in incorrect position.

Expected:
- Probably, a pop-up should appear over the cursor.

Gif:
- [https://i.gyazo.com/19c36dafdb100bc49381528c8197490f.gif](https://i.gyazo.com/19c36dafdb100bc49381528c8197490f.gif)

Software versions:
- VSCode Version:  1.15.0 (1.15.0)
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6 (15G1510)

Reproduces without extensions:
- Yes

data.title: Request a detailed diff between old and new Emmet
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15 x64
- OS Version: Win10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. try some old working Emmet and find out it breaks;
2. search in the github issues and go through several pages to know "it's not working in the new emmet"

Here is the issue:
the new Emmet is now replacing the old one,  and people has no choice to fallback to the old behavior.

can we have a detailed list of "what has been changed/ not working now but works before/not possible before but now OK with new" ?

without such detailed list, people will always comes up with "surprises", “Tab no longer works” #32243  is one example, and  the   “$@- is broken” #31916 is another.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Is there anyway to expand current focused editor?
data.body: I want to focus on one of the split editors with a command. Is anyway to do that?

data.title: Git:spawn ENAMETOOLONG
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:16:06.988Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions:

---|---|---

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.git add .  (in disk:E)
2.can not cancel add    For reason:Git:spawn ENAMETOOLONG
3.How Can I cancel the "git add ."?   Now,my VS Code “Source code management“ have too many items
